title: When will COVID-19 cases caused by the Omicron variant (B.1.1.529) exceed 100,000 in the UK?
preds:
I think this has already happened.
What does the ZOE / King's College London study say?
2,395,292 currently predicted to have symptomatic COVID in the UK (205,235 new cases each day), and 
(from memory now) in some highly populated areas (such as London) 90%+ of COVID cases are omicron.

I am hedging my bets here.  There is no doubt 100k was passed before 30 Dec.  But there was no publication in this week due to holidays (which was on the notes for last week, so should have spotted this issue sooner).   So next publication is 7 Jan with likely reporting to 5 Jan.  this means the first report showing more than 100k will be showing data to 5 Jan putting resolution for this question in bin 2 not bin 1.   I don’t think the report will split the 2 weeks data, but it might, so I’m assuming that the report will cover the totals to date as it is a cumulative report, with a note on the new column saying the data covers 2 weeks.  This feels in keeping with how the UK reports tend to get published. It’s a bit of a risk, but worth at least mitigating on the scores.

A question here
the data release for the past week is expected today (going by the past trend of 7 days between releases) and while the threshold of 100k cases will most certainly be crossed. Will it mean that the outcome was reached on 30th Dec 2021 and thus in the 2nd bin?
Or will it go by the true intent of the question (ie when did overall numbers exceed the 100k mark) and not just when the outcome was disclosed

As mentioned in previous comments, it has already been reached as at today there are cumulatively 177k [1]
[1] https://assets.publishing.service.gov.uk/government/uploads/system/uploads/attachment_data/file/1043908/20211228_OS_Daily_Omicron_Overview.pdf
Updated to reflect current case numbers (and after @ctsats good explanation of how the reporting structure affects the bins)

Wow, glad I read up and followed some of the great forecasts others made.
91k cumulative with 80k+ this week alone.  Almost impossible not to resolve next week.  Worth a punt on 100pc and even if it doesn’t resolve have a chance to swing back to bin 2.

Am I understanding this correctly? The number has clearly already been passed. However the resolution criteria are clear: it will be judged based on the weekly report and the next report is due on the 30th which is in the second bucket.  The fine text makes this intent clear: it refers to the report for Nov 24 as the data as of that date, not before.  The question comes down to how the resolution criteria will be judged at this point. @jayb
With a new daily sequenced high of over 23k(!) this is done at total 124.6k

Latest report ( https://www.gov.uk/government/publications/covid-19-variants-genomically-confirmed-case-numbers/variants-distribution-of-case-data-23-december-2021 ) to 22nd December has 90,906 Omicron cases.  So the next data set (to 29th December) will have well over 100K cases.  The only uncertainty I have left at this point is that the statistics continue to be made and published in the usual way.

My previous forecast [1] confused the definition of probable cases in the Omicron daily reports and probable genotyping.  I combined SGTF and confirmed omicron cases. SGTF case numbers are not included in the weekly data still [2] so that was wrong.   [1] https://www.gjopen.com/comments/1369898
[2] https://www.gov.uk/government/publications/covid-19-variants-genomically-confirmed-case-numbers/variants-distribution-of-case-data-23-december-2021 Got rid of my out of date reference thank you @ctsats

FWIW (probably nothing by now), the latest weekly report is out, and it does *not* include the SGTF cases in the probable ones; the number reported is yesterday's total confirmed cases of 90,906: https://www.gov.uk/government/publications/covid-19-variants-genomically-confirmed-case-numbers/variants-distribution-of-case-data-23-december-2021
https://twitter.com/ukhsa/status/1474041842257866759 (yesterday's total, included in the weekly report above)
Game is over; the number of confirmed cases as of today is already ~ 91K: https://twitter.com/ukhsa/status/1474041842257866759

Upping bin 1 in case question resolves on Friday and I don’t see the data.
I don’t actually think that there will be enough sequenced cases for this week, but it could happen on 31 Dec data given how quickly omicron has taken over.

Just wondering. The next weekly report is issued Dec 24 and probably will show total cases around 70-80k. 
The next weekly report is on Dec 31st and will surely hit >100k, but as this report is happening after the Dec 30th although the data is including days from before 30th, how would that contribute to the resolution of this question. Is this then a trick question in a way. Anyone has the knowledge on how this would or should be interpreted?

Today's UKHSA stat = 74,089 = 22.44% increase from yesterday.   https://twitter.com/ShaunLintern/status/1473702757253193736 Looks as though testing lag is kicking in, but still likely to hit 100k by Christmas Eve.   https://twitter.com/UncleJo46902375/status/1473701565261307906
Thanks to @paulm for pointing out today's total.

15K new cases today, for a total of 60,508. https://twitter.com/UKHSA/status/1473324700860399620 And still, these are only the confirmed ones; I suspect that the next weekly report may include the SGTF to the probable ones (I can easily imagine that they simply did not have the time to enforce consistency between the reports last week), and the question gets resolved on Friday.

As of 19th Dec, there were 45,250 cases of Omicron confirmed across the UK [1]. WIth another 8k reported on Monday alone [2], the number of days before 55,000 cases are reached ought to be seven. This would be in line with my earlier predictions though the number reported is higher than I had anticipated. The chance of these being reported within the next nine days is therefore far higher than I had predicted though I would still assert that there is a chance the reporting is delayed and it moves into January. [2] https://news.sky.com/story/covid-19-uk-records-91-743-daily-coronavirus-cases-and-44-deaths-12500804

It seems that I couldn't even predict how soon I will update the forecast. Just looked at Our World in Data (where Omicron share is nearing 40%)
https://ourworldindata.org/explorers/coronavirus-data-explorer?facet=none&Metric=Omicron+variant+%28share%29&Interval=New+per+day&Relative+to+Population=false&Align+outbreaks=false&country=GBR~USA @GMR & @belikewater  had it spot on (among others)

Omicron has come up so quickly that even with sequences alone, the question could resolve in bin 1. My remaining concern is that sequencing could fall off dramatically next week. Of course, if they start including SGTF cases in the report this week, the question will be over.
Update owing to @GMR & @belikewater  Graduated increase in B1 - I will likely do more frequent updates in the next few days.

Total Omicron cases sequenced to date: 45,145, including another 8,044 today. So for next week's report up to 22nd December we should be at 61-69k total, based on past weeks throughput capacity, and the proportion of sequenced cases that are Omicron is increasing. 
Total SGTF cases now at 124,954, after adding over 25k today, so with these 'probable' cases it would be game over already.
As an indicator, SGTF cases were at 62.85% Omicron on 15th, climbing at approx 5% per day. Even if the sequencing rate drops to an average 10k per day (in total), then at anything over 70% prevalence for Omicron should clear 100k around 28-29th December. This is without any 'probable' cases. 
I think there will undoubtedly be a few days with lower counts due to staff shortages through holidays and illness, but while only 4 lighthouse labs test for SGTF, sequencing is carried out through a large network comprised of NHS organisations, the four Public Health Agencies of the UK, the Wellcome Sanger Institute and twelve academic partners, which should help average out daily capacity to some degree.
It is perhaps not an absolute certainty at this point, but we should be 4-9k ahead of the doubtful range imho for 22nd December, so I'll hold and monitor for now.
Raising bin 1 because they added 12k sequenced cases in 1 day, which is unexpectedly impressive. Let's see how the next couple days go.

"The UK Health Security Agency said on Twitter there had been an additional 12,133 confirmed cases of Omicron over the previous 24 hours, taking the total number of confirmed cases to 37,101." https://nationalpost.com/pmn/health-pmn/uk-reports-a-further-12133-confirmed-omicron-cases-in-24-hours at 10k+/day it'll cross 100k in 6 days, but it's accelerating so is likely 4-5... time to go all in...
Another 48%+ rise today.  Way ahead of schedule.

Background 	• 24th of November 2021: South Africa report variant B.1.1.529 (now Omicron) to the WHO [1]
	• 27th of November 2021: UK gov press release confirming 2 UK cases linked to travel to South Africa [2]
	• 15 December 2021: UKHSA Omicron risk assessment states Omicron has a growth advantage over Delta, and is at least as transmissible as delta. Antibody 
           neutralisation data shows reduction in immune protection but There is insufficient evidence on infection severity [3]


Omicron Case Numbers  Omicron daily reports show confirmed Omicron cases which I suspect under-report cases, and S gene target failure (SGTF) cases in which the spike protein gene is not detected. UKHSA are using SGTF to ID Omicron [4], which are deemed to be probable cases [5]. With 2 important caveats: 1. the alpha variant also exhibits SGTF but is at very low levels unlikely to inflate Omicron case numbers. 2. Not all labs are capable of identifying SGTF (possible that only 4 can, although unconfirmed[6]). The following combines both confirmed Omicron and SGTF (probable omicron)
16th Dec  2021 +14,245, total: 49,138.Total: ^41% [7]
17th Dec  2021 +19,679, total: 68,790. Total: ^40% [8]
18th Dec  2021 +32,957, total: 101,673. Total: ^48% [9]
19th Dec  2021 +35,162, total: 136,548. Total: ^34% [10] Given we've already hit >100k cases for both confirmed and probable the questions answer should be confirmed when the next update is released by UKHSA. Another update:
 - official data to 15th Dec (https://www.gov.uk/government/publications/covid-19-variants-genomically-confirmed-case-numbers/variants-distribution-of-case-data-17-december-2021) has 10,017 cases, up from 568 to 8th Dec, and 32 to 1st Dec.
 - current total in the news is 24,968 cases (https://news.sky.com/story/covid-19-10-059-more-omicron-cases-recorded-in-uk-three-times-as-many-as-yesterday-12499092), up from 4,713 five days before and 134 nine days before that.
 - if anything this is slightly faster than doubling every two days.
 - I definitely see people behaving more cautiously, but not drastically so, and even if stricter measures are put in place there's a lag before changes in behaviour affect case numbers.
 - overall I'm now even more confident we'll reach 100,000 cases before the 30th of December.  Quite possibly in the next data set expected 22nd December.

@Ed321 Unfortunately Covid-19’s also a super mutator. This mutation seems to be less deadly especially in the vaccinated and the U.K.has done a better than average job in the wealthy nations in getting its population vaccinated.

Not aligned with the consensus currently, I wonder if we are overestimating the growth rate based on South Africa where the fully-vaccinated population proportion is 25% as opposed to UK where it is 65%. @belikewater what do you think?

We now have seen in a weekly update of the 'official' data that the UKHSA update on their Twitter pages matches our confirmed sequenced data. That total went up by 5 and then 10k and is now at 25k. The speed of increase is rapid and even if it went up linearly we could add another 100k by the 30th. It is more likely to continue to go up exponentially for a while still, especially until Christmas when we might see a reduction in testing capacity and demand.
I am not going all in like some but still find it quite likely.
Given 10000 cases today and the delay in testing I think it will happen in Jan.

I was going to comment on the curiosity of SGTF to this question. How SGTF testing is only used in four lighthouse laboratories around the UK and therefore is not reliable for providing a geographic representation of Omicron due to regional dead spots, but still very valuable to gauge the speed of spread and prevalence. UKHSA now list confirmed cases (via whole-genome sequencing or genotyping) and SGTF cases, on their daily overview: cumulative data, but while SGTF is not included in that total confirmed and probable set (yet), they do list SGTF as 'probable' cases via the Daily Briefing report Summary... curious.
Anyway, I was going to comment on that, then I saw that over 10k cases have just been reported as confirmed in a single day. 10,059 for a total of 24,968.
So sequencing capacity appears to have increased, compared to previous weekly high of 64k. SGTF cases were at 62.85% on 15th, climbing from 56.91% on 14th. These indicators suggest the total will exceed 100k within 12 days, even with a drop in sequencing over holiday periods.
I agree with the earlier comments, so reassessing before a new update.

@belikewater 's comment https://www.gjopen.com/comments/1368974 did an excellent job of putting perspective on the question.  It's moving fast, and there are a lot of unknowns, so best moderate assumptions until we've got more info

https://www.gov.uk/government/publications/covid-19-variants-genomically-confirmed-case-numbers
Question is asking cumulatively when 100k will be passed on the “total confirmed and probable” case numbers. Cases reported this week are cumulative over 10k now, with 9k extra reported in the week.
Given the very high levels of testing and reported cases, there are a lot more cases to sequence.  Numbers sequences this week are a little lower than last week at about 105k so the proportion of omicron cases had increased significantly There are 90k cases needed to meet this question with 2 more reporting weeks before the end of December.  
People are talking about cases doubling every 2 to 3 days. This does bring us into the 100k territory, but it assume cases and testing will remain high and increasing over the new whole of the next two weeks.  If we think about where we are, the week before last there were loads of Christmas parties.  This week everyone was encouraged to work from home and the schools are starting to finish.  Next week everyone will have been taking precautions and schools will have finished. This week and next lots of people will take lots of testing to avoid Christmas being ruined.  So if we have a 10 day infection window, early this week will be the peak from the exposures the week before last.  Cases should start tailing off then as people started to be cautious.
Once Christmas Day is reached people will mix and cause another peak in Jan.
So late this week and into next cases could slow down, limiting the likelihood of getting to 100k.  
However this is all my speculation (optimism?)
I’m increasing the likelihood of December, but still not fully sure.

Rethinking. 61k samples were sequenced (not genotyped) in the week starting Nov 28, and probably ~64k were sequenced in the week starting Dec 5 (projecting forward): https://sars2.cvr.gla.ac.uk/cog-uk/
They have not been using their standard genotyping assay with Omicron, presumably because just looking for SGTF or 69-70 deletion is a lot easier. They may not use their usual genotyping assay at all. If they start reporting SGTF/69-70 deletion samples (now considered probable cases) in the data used to resolve this question, it will resolve next week. If they only report sequences, then it is trickier. Perhaps we can expect ~70% of sequenced samples in the data reported Dec 24 to be Omicron. Let's say 65k sequences * 0.7 = 45k Omicron. 45k + 10k = 55k. Nearly all sequences in the final report of the year will be Omicron. But how much will they sequence that week? If next week comes in at ~55k (sequence data only), then I'll lower my forecast, as I don't want to rely on sequences to get us to 100k during the holidays. But I'm going to bet that they'll start reporting probable cases.

I am not expecting the definitions of this report to change.
I am expecting high numbers sequenced again this coming week, over 100k total.
30 to 40k omicron could be sampled, will watch the UKHSA updates to see if this is looking higher or lower.
Will come down to the final week. 
Quite likely that numbers will be heading towards 100k but I am not certain on the number sequenced in the final week.

Data is still ahead of the 2-3 day doubling schedule I drew up last week which predicted passing 100k on the 28th, but adjusting a little further down for uncertainty.   https://twitter.com/chrischirp/status/1471900234548715521
Small decrease for uncertainty over sustained accurate reporting, as per Prof. Christina Pagel's comments re: LFT availability & PCR processing in today's Independent Sage meeting.

Data 💣! After discussion with @ctsats, it seems wise to reduce the bin 1 forecast: https://www.gjopen.com/comments/1368964 The crux of the matter is that the UKHSA changed the case definitions; the new case definitions went into effect on Dec 14. A probable case is now "COVID-19 PCR positive and i) SGTF^^ or ii) 69-70 deletion with specimen dates from 1 December" (from the Dec 15 daily report; also as found by @paulm originally). Also, they don't seem to be genotyping Omicron cases using their standard genotyping assay. So the only Omicron cases in the Dec 17 weekly report are sequenced: 10,017 cases. Meanwhile, there are an additional ~19k probable cases. This question would resolve next week if they included all of those. It's somewhat understandable that they're not including their probable cases in this week's report as the case definitions changed partway through the week. But are they going to start including them next week or not? If they don't, then this question would almost certainly take longer to resolve. The week starting Nov 21, they sequenced 58k samples. The following week, 61k. Looking at the pattern at https://sars2.cvr.gla.ac.uk/cog-uk/ , I think we can expect the number of sequenced samples to grow at most slightly through the rest of the year and possibly fall because of the holidays. Maybe 64k for the week starting Dec 5, more for successive weeks, maybe less during the holidays. If only sequenced data are used to resolve this question, nearly all of next week's and the following week's sequences would need to be Omicron. And if the number sequenced falls in the week after Christmas, it won't happen. So, I'm adjusting far lower until we know whether they're including SGTF data next week. If they do include SGTF data starting in next week's report, then the question will resolve in bin 1, and my Brier score will be damaged. If they don't, it'll also be less than ideal. But I suppose that's better than the risk of even worse scores.

Sticking at 100 until this afternoon's figures are released, however Christina Pagel (Director of the Clinical Operational Research Unit at UCL) has just said there's still a shortage of LFTs in some areas of the UK + PCR testing is currently delayed.  She's expecting a data crunch that will make UK figures unreliable. Relevant parts between 10' and 15' minutes in, although Pagel's whole segment is worth watching. https://youtu.be/MjU6zwL_4GU

Based on UK Methodology and doubling rate of ~2 days:  https://assets.publishing.service.gov.uk/government/uploads/system/uploads/attachment_data/file/1041809/20211216_Omicron_daily_infection_estimation_modelling.pdf

New definitions should mean that SGTF cases are included in our result. This will mean that we are 47k as of now. COuld potentially be over 100k by this next report but will need to see if the report includes them. I feel that it is OK to increase my forecast high until the next report confirms or denies our result

Case definition has been changed as of 14th. It will still be interesting to see the next report, but bin 1 now looks overwhelmingly likely.
But will people stop getting tested nearer Christmas, to avoid quarantine? Confirmed cases have only increased by 1,691 today, to 11,708 (lower than expected).

I saw that case definitions had changed, and @paulm found what the change actually is: the UHKSA is now considering confirmed cases to be sequenced and genotyped cases, and they're considering probable cases to be SGTF samples that meet certain criteria: https://www.gjopen.com/comments/1368439
With that definition of probable cases, bin 1 is now assured.

Don't want to get left behind by the crowd. So am raising my 1
Do I think UK will have 100k in December? Yes, 100%
Do I think that the variant distribution of case data that will resolve the question will give the same number as the cases? No, 0%
Will the resolving data hit 100k in December? Hmmm, I am not going over 80 till I get at least one more data point.

"More than 10,000 cases of Omicron have been recorded." https://www.aljazeera.com/news/2021/12/15/uk-reports-record-daily-covid-cases-with-rapid-omicron-spread We've still got to remember that this is still confirmed and probable, so is dependent on testing. The Dec 10 report only shows 536, but if the article is correct that should be changing rapidly and we've got 3 more reporting periods in the first box. Considering they're testing ~110k/report, and if the growth rate is to be believed, it's not a stretch anymore to think it will be bin 1. I'm going to swing hard as I think this is an exponential growth question and the terrain is changing very, very quickly.

Omicron entered the UK on the 27th November [1], and as at 15th December, the official publicised number is 4,713 cases with the first death reported on the 13th December [2]. Of the total cases, 48% are estimated to be Omicron [3], with forecasts predicting that Omicron will soon outpace all other variants in infection rates [4].  If we use the spread of Alpha and Delta as our base rates, caveated with Omicron's more pernicious ability to spread a reasonable prediction ought to be likely. Alpha cases took from the 4th Jan to the 30th April to reach 100,000 cases. [5] This is 117 days. The Delta case took from circa March 2nd to June 25th to reach 100,000 cases [4,5,6]. This is 116 days. With both of these being approximately similar despite Delta being a more pervasive and quickly spreading variant, one might postulate that the government measures implemented [7] were able to somewhat stifle the spread of COVID-19. My base rate is therefore 116.5 days from the first case to 100,000. This would put the predicted 100,000 case rate at 24th March 2022. However, Delta took 91 days to become the most prolific variant [4]. Whereas Omicron has taken just 18 days to reach 48% of total cases [2]. With cases of the Omicron variant forecasted to double every 2-3 days [8] one might reasonably assume that within 21 days it will be the largest variant.  With the WHO, Oxford University and WSJ all touting [9,10,11] that the Omicron variant can lower the immune system and people that are vaccinated are still not immune (the benefits being lowered risk of severe condition or death), it is reasonable to assume that the Omicron variant is not limited to infecting the unvaccinated populus.  If we do the calculations based on Omicron doubling every 2.5 days with a current rate of roughly 5,000 (that are reported - we are assuming that the 100,000 mark is only surpassed on reported cases as some suggest we are already passed on non-reported).
+2.5 days = 10k total cases
+2.5 = 20k
+2.5 = 40k
+2.5 = 80k
+2.5 = 160k This would indicate that within 11 days we will surpass the total of 100,000 cases caused by the Omicron variant alone. This takes us to the 26th December. To do some dialectical bootstrapping - basically to make sure I'm not under confirmation bias, let's look at why it may take much longer.
Schools and Universities are mostly still in session [12] meaning that young people are still socialising a lot and on return to their homes, from circa 17th Dec there may once again be a relative drop off in the number of cases.
With COVID restrictions having been more focused on testing with free offers from the govt [13] e.g. for workplaces, parties, travel - there may be an increase in the % of cases that were reported which may once again fall as people go home for Christmas and no longer test as regularly.
Workplace Christmas parties (no puns on BoJo for now) have mainly taken place prior to the governments' announcements and have not explicitly been banned meaning that a spike in cases may have been seen at so-called 'super spreader' work parties [14] with rates falling once people go home. In spite of this, there is nationwide distrust of the UK government, including calls for a vote of no-confidence [15] and the police are fearing backlash of non compliance by the public [16]. This may mean that people feel less guilty or perceive a lesser social stigma around breaking the rules.  I would therefore anticipate that whilst the 26th December is likely the earliest that we might expect to see 100,000 cases, the first week of January with returns to offices, schools and therefore increased testing is the more likely time to have 100,000 actually reported. I would therefore place a 37% potential with it being ahead of the 30th December and a 59% potential before the end of January with just 3% remaining split over the following months. Today's Omicron total = 5906 cases.  This is just over a 25% rise on yesterday - a considerable drop from the huge daily increases we've seen over the last week.  If recorded daily rises stick at around 25% per day we'll still hit the first bucket, however if this sudden drop is due to a processing issue, it could slow further.  On the other hand, it could also just indicate weekend lab lag.  Either way, Omicron has now outrun Delta in London & expect other regions to catch up in following days. Time to update my previous estimate.

As always, note that this question isn't asking when there will 100k cases caused by Omicron, but when 100k cases will be genetically characterized (sequenced or genotyped) as Omicron. Each week, ~85k-110k samples are genetically characterized, and so each week, a fraction of those will be characterized as Omicron cases. If Omicron causes half of all cases in a given week, then about half of all samples characterized that week will be characterized as Omicron, regardless of how many more cases Omicron actually causes. After discussion with @kevins and @paulm, increasing the weight on bin 1 in case they just say, whatever, we're going to call SGTF results Omicron cases. For those just starting this question, please note that it's not asking when there will be 100k Omicron case in the UK, it's asking when 100k samples will be *genetically characterized* as Omicron. Currently, that means *sequenced* as Omicron. ~85k-~100k samples/week are genetically characterized (sequenced or genotyped), but only ~40k samples are sequenced each week. So, for example, if there are 300k Delta cases and 100k Omicron cases in a given week, then that'll show up as ~10k Omicron cases for the purposes of this question. That would change if they start using a new genotyping assay or just calling SGTF results good enough. Other than that, my previous forecast and the discussion below it still hold: https://www.gjopen.com/comments/1363205

Currently ~300,000 infections/week in UK, mostly Delta. Between April 19th and May 31st, Delta went from being 1% of cases to being >70%, or 56 days. 134 Omicron cases in UK at the time of writing, and we can assume that's an under-count since we don't sequence every.  Published on April 19th https://inews.co.uk/news/health/indian-variant-cases-new-covid-strain-uk-figures-latest-news-963434 gives a good base case for us being at a similar point right now - less than 200 cases of Delta in the UK at that point. There is a caveat here in that there were generally less cases in the population at that point, less than 2000/day. But we also had NPI restrictions in place.  If we take the Delta strain as an example and extrapolate, and estimate that we were at 1% of cases being Omicron today:
- By 18th we will be at 10%
- By the 1st Jan we will be at 33% Assuming constant number of cases (e.g. 300k a week)
- Right now 400/day
- 18th we will be getting 4000/day
- 1st Jan 12,500/day With that growth we'd expect 75,000 cases by Jan 1st. Omicron doesn't have to grow twice as quickly to reach 100,000 before then. In April and May Delta tended to displace Alpha's share of infections before actually increasing the raw number of infections. I think we're likely to see a similar story. Still a lot of unknowns around how vaccine/natural immunity evasive Omicron is, so I'm putting the majority of belief into it being early Jan before we have 100,000 cases, but I think there is a good chance we see this happen in December given the amount of mixing expected and lack of NPIs. We might not know about it until well into January though.

Omicron is pretty scary, it has lots of mysterious mutations and seems to be doing well in South Africa.  It almost certainly has some advantage that's allowing it to spread as well as it is, but we don't yet know what that advantage is.  It lacks most of Delta's mutations, so may in fact turn out to be weaker in other respects (e.g. infectiousness or vaccine resistance).  We should not assume it will have the same success in the UK as in South Africa (differences in population demographics, vaccination rate, natural immunity rate, culture, climate, population density...).  All this is to say, I don't think it's quite a given yet that Omicron will become widespread in the UK (10% chance it doesn't). That said, evidence so far suggests it probably is spreading successfully in the UK. Starting point 3rd December: 104 total confirmed reported cases in England, 29 Scotland, 1 Wales. A total of 134 UK-wide, and these are widely distributed, so seeding is a given, and there are signs of community transmission: https://www.gov.uk/government/news/covid-19-variants-identified-in-the-uk Total genomically sequenced cases = 32 as of 1st December. (Roughly 0.034% of those sampled)
https://www.gov.uk/government/publications/covid-19-variants-genomically-confirmed-case-numbers/variants-distribution-of-case-data-3-december-2021
Sequenced cases will always be a sub-group of the total number reported, dependant on the throughput capacity of sequencing available. A few forecasters seem to be mixing up reported cases with those that are genetically characterised. Dealing with reported cases only, I'm adjusting from SA data on transmission to give a doubling rate approx 4.5-6 days due to the different environment and context, particularly the low vaccination level in SA. From 134 current reported cases, I'd estimate 8-12k reported by year end. In terms of prevalence that could be 3-5%, with Delta cases still at 40-45k/day, unless further mitigation is started promptly (unlikely given the Government track record for additional mandates only as a last resort).  Translating this into confirmed or probable genotyped samples, 3-5% would equate to 2,500-4,000 samples out of approx 90k/wk. Sampling rates vary but maximum capacity looks to be 95k/wk, having increased from ~50k six months ago as a new facility (the Rosalind Franklin Laboratory) gets fully up to speed. https://www.gov.uk/government/news/rosalind-franklin-laboratory-processes-one-millionth-pcr-test From this level January results are likely to show Omicron gaining prevalence quickly, particularly through vaccine immunity escape and some greater transmissibility compared to Delta. I'd expect at least 3-4 weeks for Omicron to reach 50% dominance in this context even so. If sampling backs this up, then we could exceed 100k either in the 3rd week of January (fastest likely) or by 1st week in February (slowest likely). Given the report date to 26th Jan is within bin 2, this does look the favourite, but any slower rate will go into bin3, so it's still open. Caveats: there may be some query around the number of  'probable' cases of  Omicron due to the "S-gene dropout" which can help quickly establish likelihood, but not confirmation. Full genomic sequencing would still be needed, so this is perhaps not a big factor to this question. The general public will take some self-imposed precautions but without clear guidance and mandates this won't be enough to prevent Omicron spreading. More drastic measures could well be imposed after Christmas, similar to last year, as the Government belatedly recognises that the NHS is under much more pressure than it has acknowledged, and that cases and deaths have not improved. Any mitigating effects should favour bin3, as anything later than this currently looks overly optimistic.

There's some uncertainty to this because we don't yet have much data that tells us how dominant (or not) Omicron is against Delta, but preliminary data does suggest Omicron might well be dominant.
With that in mind, as well as the currently high number of daily cases that is expected to remain high (and most likely, increase), it's only a matter of time until most (trending towards all) daily cases are Omicron cases.
How long this takes will depend on how dominant Omicron is against Delta. For reference, Delta became dominant in less than two months and is considered ~1.5 times more likely to cause an infection compared to Alpha in the UK (https://www.publichealth.columbia.edu/public-health-now/news/delta-variant-60-percent-more-contagious-original-virus-and-evades-immunity). If this were to hold for Omicron vs Delta then it seems very likely that 100k cases (*confirmed or probable*) could be reached by the end of January. In particular, Delta appeared during spring, a period that included some restrictions, more outdoor activities and vaccines, as opposed to winter, which as we saw last year can accommodate many cases even if there are restrictions (although there were no vaccines last winter).
If Omicron is not dominant over Delta e.g., if it is equally likely to cause an infection, then it could take a moderate amount of time to reach 100k cases (*confirmed or probable*) because Delta will remain the most probable source of infection for some time.
If Delta remains the dominant variant then Omicron could disappear quite quickly, or at least occur very rarely in the confirmed or probable cases, as other variants of concern did in France for example once Delta became dominant.
Because of the preliminary evidence indicating Omicron might spread much more than Delta, my initial outcome distribution is going to tend towards the end of January.

Ok, people who worked on the previous similar question about Delta, we got this! For those of you who are new to these data, here's a key point to keep in mind: this question isn't asking when there will be >100k cases in the UK that are caused by Omicron. It's asking when >100k samples will be genetically characterized as Omicron cases. As only a portion of cases are genetically characterized each week, this question asks 1) how fast Omicron is going to spread in the UK relative to Delta, and 2) when that will lead to >100k Omicron cases being genetically characterized.  UK labs characterized just under 76k samples last week. The number characterized stays relatively constant, so what matters most to this question is the week-by-week percentage of cases that Omicron represents. Omicron cases currently represent about 0.3% of cases in England, so I'll go with that as the best currently available prevalence data for the UK. The current data on the website are for cases up to Nov 17, and there are zero reported Omicron cases up to then. The UK currently reports ~44k cases/day; 0.003 * 44k = 132. So, seeding with ~132 cases today (it won't be completely accurate, but it's a starting point), with cases quadrupling in just over a week (South African data), we should see somewhere in the ballpark of 18k cases by Dec 29. If the UK continues to see ~44k/day Delta cases, then these will be a small fraction of total cases and hence a small fraction of the genetically characterized cases. I think this makes bin 1 extremely unlikely. Delta will likely peak in early January, but Omicron won't. Omicron cases will likely rise dramatically in the UK in January unless substantial mitigations are put in place. It is starting to look like it's more contagious than Delta, and it largely escapes existing immunity, so in the absence of serious mitigations, it will likely spread like wildfire. While there might be, say, ~0.6M Delta cases in January (probably an overestimate), there could be >2M Omicron cases (or more) in the UK in January, depending on exactly how well Omicron spreads and whether the UK government and people attempt to mitigate its spread. If there were 2M Omicron cases and 0.6M Delta cases in January before Jan 26, then Omicron cases would represent 77% of all cases in January. And there could even be close to 4M Omicron cases in January in the absence of mitigations; I sincerely hope that they do put some mitigations in place before everything gets out of control. In any case, if 76k cases/week are genetically characterized, and at least half of them are Omicron cases starting in early January, then even with mitigations, over 4 * 76k/2 = 152k Omicron cases might be characterized by Jan 26. In fact, if there are even 3 weeks in Jan where Omicron represents at least 1/2 of all cases (and I don't currently see how this won't happen), then 100k will be reached. I think this makes bin 2 extremely likely. Mitigations may delay the appearance of 100k cases in the UK data until later bins, so I will assign some probability to those. And I leave open the possibility that by some miracle, Omicron won't spread well in the UK.
